title-group.article-title: Synthesis and characterization of cationic surfactants in the preparation of organobentonite and study their effectiveness on the properties of styrene-butadiene rubber/bentonite composites

article-meta.aff: 1Polymer and Pigment Department, National Research Center, Dokki, Cairo, Egypt
2Petrochemical Department, Egyptian Petroleum Research Institute, Nasr City, Cairo, Egypt

author-notes.corresp: A. I. Khalaf, Polymer and Pigment Department, National Research Center, Dokki, Cairo 12622, Egypt. Email: aman2502003@yahoo.com

abstract.p: Two cationic surfactants (N-isopropyl-N, N-dimethyldodecan-1-aminium bromide (S1) and N-isopropyl-N, N-dimethylhexadecan-1-aminium bromide (S2)) are synthesized. The chemical structure of the synthesized surfactants was confirmed by Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) and 1H Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. Critical micelle concentration (CMC) of the synthesized cationic surfactants was determined. CMC decreased with increasing alkyl chain length. Organobentonites are prepared using cationic surfactants (S1 and S2) and characterized by x-ray diffraction (XRD), FTIR spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy. Results of XRD, FTIR, SEM and TGA showed that the surfactants were intercalated into the interlamellar space of bentonite. Organobentonites fillers were added to styrene-butadiene rubber and cured by conventional vulcanization system. The filler loading was varied from 0 to 10 parts per hundred parts of rubber (phr). The compounds were characterized with respect to their curing characteristics and mechanical properties. The vulcanization rate and torque value of the organobentonites compounds are sensibly higher than the unmodified bentonite compound.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Surfactants are amphiphilic materials containing both apolar long-chain hydrocarbon ‘tail’ and polar, usually ionic, ‘head’ groups. Due to their unique structure, they can drastically modify the interfacial properties.

Organo-montmorillonites are synthesized by introducing cationic surfactants such as quaternary ammonium compounds into the interlayer space through ion exchange. 1,2 Long-chain alkylammonium cations can form a hydrophobic medium within the clay interlayer, and act in analogy to a bulk organic phase. Intercalation of an organic surfactant between the clay layers can not only change the surface properties from hydrophilic to hydrophobic but also significantly increase the basal spacing of the layers. These clays may then have useful properties, for example, the removal of oil from water, the removal of toxic chemicals from water and removal of humic materials from water. These modified minerals (organoclays) represent a family of materials which have a lot of applications in a range of key areas, such as adsorbents for organic pollutants, rheological control agents, reinforcing fillers for plastics and electric materials. 3

Clays and clay minerals, such as montmorillonite, saponite, hectorite, and so on, were widely used as filler for rubber and plastic for many years, for saving polymer consumption and reducing the cost. 4,5 The clay minerals are composed of silicate layers of 1 nm thickness and 200–300 nm in the lateral dimensions. 6 The internal and external cations can be exchanged by other inorganic or by organic ions 7 ; for example, quaternary alkyl ammonium ions. Organophilic modification makes the silicate compatible with the polymer.

Different methods have been used to prepare rubber/silicate nanocomposites having excellent properties and unique phase structure, such as polyurethane, 8,9 acrylonitrile-butadiene rubber, 10 ethylene-propylene-diene monomer, 11,12 natural rubber (NR), 13 butadiene rubber and styrene-butadiene rubber (SBR) 14 –16 and butyl rubber. 17 Generally, rubber/clay nanocomposites are prepared by in situ polymerization, solution and melt intercalation, where in organically modified layered silicate must be used. The present work aims to prepare cationic surfactants (N-isopropyl-N, N-dimethyldodecan-1-aminium bromide (S1) and N-isopropyl-N, N-dimethylhexadecan-1-aminium bromide (S2)), and their uses to modify bentonite and study their effeteness on the properties of SBR/bentonite composites.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: The bentonite used in this study was obtained from Sigma-Aldrich (product code B3378; Munich, Germany). Bentonite has a cationic exchange capacity of 88 mequiv/100 g and surface area of 39.3 m2 g−1. N,N-Dimethylpropan-2-amine, 1-bromohexadecane and 1-bromododecane were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. (Munich, Germany). SBR 1502, with a specific gravity of 0.945, supplied by ESSO Chemie (Hamburg, Germany) was used. Zinc oxide and stearic acid were used as activators with specific gravity of 5.55–5.61 and 0.90–0.97, respectively, at 15°C. N-Cyclohexyl-2-benzothiazole sulfenamide, a pale gray powder, with specific gravity of 1.27–1.31 at room temperature (25 ± 1°C) and melting point 95–100°C and tetramethyl thiuram disulfide, an odorless powder, with specific gravity 1.29–1.31, melting point 148.5°C were used as accelerators. Elemental sulfur, a fine pale yellow powder, with specific gravity of 2.04–2.06 at room temperature was used as vulcanizing agent. Polymerized 2, 2, 4-trimethyl-1,2-dihydroquinoline was used as antioxidant.
All the rubber ingredients were of commercial grades, purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co.

sec.title: Instrumentation
sec.p:
1 H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) was measured in dimethyl sufoxide using Jeol ECA 500 MHz NMR spectrometer, at 500 MHz. Critical micelle concentration (CMC) of surfactants was measured at 25°C using a Due Nouy platinum ring method with Krüss K6 tensiometer. X-Ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed on Philip’s x-ray diffractometer PW1390 with Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation at generator voltage of 40 KV and wavelength of 0.154 nm at room temperature. The diffraction angle, 2θ, was scanned at a rate of 2°min−1. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were obtained at room temperature using a Jascow FTIR-430 (Japan) Instrument. The scanning range was from 520 to 4000 cm−1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted with Shimadzu TGA-50H. Atypical sample weight was about 8–10 mg, and the analysis was performed at a heating rate of 10°C min−1 from 50 to 600°C under nitrogen atmosphere. Transmission electron micrographs of pure clay and nanoclay were obtained using a JEOL JX 1230 TEM with microanalyzer electron probe. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was carried out using the electron microscope model JXA 840A JEOL electron probe microanalyzer (Japan). The samples were mounted on a standard specimen stub, coated with a very thin layer of gold. Cure characteristics, such as minimum torque (M L), maximum torque (M H), optimum cure time (Tc90), scorch time (Ts2) and cure rate index (CRI), were determined according to ASTM-D 2084-07 using a Monsanto (Akron, Ohio, USA) rheometer 100 at 152 ± 1°C. Mechanical properties, the tensile strength, modulus at 100% elongation and elongation at break were carried out at room temperature on a tensile testing Machine, Zwick 1425, according to ASTM-D 412-06. The equilibrium swelling of the rubber vulcanizates was carried out according to ASTM-D 573(2007). The equilibrium swelling Q% was calculated according to 1
Q % =
w s

w b

w b

× 100
where wb and ws are the weight of the sample before and after swelling in toluene, respectively, for 24 h at room temperature.

sec.title: Synthesis of S1
sec.p: The used cationic surfactant in this study was synthesized as shown in Figure 1 by quaternization reaction of N,N-dimethylpropan-2-amine (0.95 g, 0.1 mol) and 1-bromododecane (24.92 g, 0.1 mol) in ethanol at 70°C for 48 h to produce N-isopropyl-N,N-dimethyldodecan-1-aminium bromide (S1). The mixture was allowed to cool. The obtained white precipitate was further purified by diethyl ether and then recrystallized by ethanol.

sec.title: Synthesis of S2
sec.p: The used cationic surfactant in this study was synthesized as shown in Figure 2 by quaternization reaction of N,N-dimethylpropan-2-amine (0.95 g, 0.1 mol) and 1-bromohexadecane (24.92 g, 0.1 mol) in ethanol at 70°C for 48 h to produce N-isopropyl-N,N-dimethylhexadecan-1-aminium bromide (S2). The mixture was allowed to cool. The obtained white precipitate was further purified by diethyl ether and then recrystallized by ethanol.

sec.title: Preparation of nanoclay
sec.p: Bentonite (20 g) was dispersed into 1000 mL of hot distilled water (80°C) with continuous stirring. Surfactants S1 and S2 were dissolved in 500 mL of hot distilled water (80°C) and this suspension of clay was stirred vigorously for 1 h. Then, this solution was poured into the hot clay water dispersion under vigorous stirring for 50 min to flocculate the clay. The precipitate was collected on a filter, washed several times until no bromide ions were detected in the filtrate by testing with silver nitrate (0.1 mol L−1) with 500 mL of hot distilled water (80°C), and dried to yield the organoclay. The dried product was ground in a mortar into powder and its average particle size was calculated by transmission electron microscopy (TEM).

sec.title: SBR composites preparation
sec.p: Rubber compounds were prepared in an open two-roll mill at room temperature according to ASTM-D 3182-07. The speed of the slow roll is 24 rev min−1, with a gear ratio of 1:1.4. The compounded rubbers were left overnight before vulcanization. The vulcanization was carried out at 152 ± 1°C for SBR in an electrically heated press under a pressure of about 4 MPa to get vulcanized rubber sheets of 2 mm thickness. The formulations of the compounds are described in Table 1.

fn.p: SBR: styrene-butadiene rubber; phr: parts per hundred parts of rubber; S1: N-isopropyl-N, N-dimethyldodecan-1-aminium bromide; S2: N-isopropyl-N, N-dimethylhexadecan-1-aminium bromide; TQM: polymerized 2, 2,4-trimethyl 1,2dihydroquinoline; CBS: N-cyclohexyl-2-benzothiazole sulfenamide; TMTD: tetramethylthiuram disulfide.

sec.title: Characterization of the synthesized cationic surfactants
sec.p: The chemical structure of the synthesized cationic surfactants was confirmed by FTIR and 1 H NMR spectroscopy, and the CMC was determined.

sec.title: Critical micelle concentration
sec.p: The CMC was determined from surface tension measurements at 25°C and listed in Table 2. 18 The obtained CMC values of the synthesized surfactants (S1 and S2) show a decreasing trend with increasing hydrophobic moiety. This can be accounted for the decreased hydration in the hydrophilic part, which favors micellization.

caption.p: CMC of the synthesized cationic surfactants from surface tension measurements at 25°C.

sec.title: FTIR spectrum of S1
sec.p: FTIR spectrum of the synthesized cationic surfactant showed the following absorption bands at 723 cm−1 ((CH2)n rocking), 1389 cm−1 (CH symmetric bending), 2852 cm−1 (CH symmetric stretching), 2920 cm−1 (CH asymmetric stretching) and 1051 cm−1 (C–N+). FTIR spectrum of the synthesized inhibitor is shown in Figure 3. The FTIR spectra confirmed the expected function groups in the synthesized cationic surfactant.

caption.p: Fourier transform infrared spectrum of N-isopropyl-N,N-dimethyldodecan-1-aminium bromide.

sec.title: 1 H NMR spectrum of the synthesized S1
sec.p: 1 H NMR spectrum of the synthesized cationic surfactant showed different bands at δ = 0.81 ppm (t, 3H, NCH2CH2(CH2)9CH 3); δ = 1.22 ppm (m, 18H, NCH2CH2(CH 2)9CH3); δ = 1.60 ppm (m, 2H, NCH2CH 2(CH2)9CH3); δ = 2.89 ppm (t, 2H, NCH 2CH2(CH2)9CH3); δ = 1.22 ppm (s, 6H, (CH 3)2CH–N); δ = 3.30 ppm (t, 3H, (CH3)2CH–N); δ = 3.63 ppm (t, 3H, (CH 3)2–N). 1 H NMR spectrum of the synthesized inhibitor is shown in Figure 4. The data of 1 H NMR spectra confirmed the expected hydrogen proton distribution in the synthesized cationic surfactant.

caption.p: 1 H nuclear magnetic resonance spectrum of the synthesized N-isopropyl-N,N-dimethyldodecan-1-aminium bromide.

sec.title: FTIR spectrum of S2
sec.p: FTIR spectrum of the synthesized gemini surfactant showed the following absorption bands at 722 cm−1 ((CH2)n rocking), 1389 cm−1 (CH3 symmetric bending), 2851 cm−1 (CH symmetric stretching), 2920 cm−1 (CH asymmetric stretching) and 1051 cm−1 (C–N+). FTIR spectrum of the synthesized inhibitor is shown in Figure 5. The FTIR spectra confirmed the expected function groups in the synthesized cationic surfactant.

caption.p: Fourier transform infrared spectrum of N-isopropyl-N,N-dimethylhexadecan-1-aminium bromide.

sec.title: 1 H NMR spectrum of the synthesized S2
sec.p: The 1 H NMR spectrum of the synthesized cationic surfactant showed different bands at δ = 0.81 ppm (t, 3H, NCH2CH2(CH2)9CH 3); δ = 1.20 ppm (m, 18H, NCH2CH2(CH 2)9CH3); δ = 1.60 ppm (m, 2H, NCH2CH 2(CH2)9CH3); δ = 2.88 ppm (t, 2H, NCH 2CH2(CH2)9CH3); δ = 1.22 ppm (s, 6H, (CH 3)2CH–N); δ = 3.41 ppm (t, 3H, (CH3)2CH–N); δ = 3.63 ppm (t, 3H, (CH 3)2–N). 1 H NMR spectrum of the synthesized inhibitor is shown in Figure 6. The data of 1 H NMR spectra confirmed the expected hydrogen proton distribution in the synthesized cationic surfactant.

caption.p: 1 H nuclear magnetic resonance spectrum of the synthesized N-isopropyl-N,N-dimethylhexadecan-1-aminium bromide.

sec.title: Characterization of the nanoclay
sec.p: The clay was modified with S1 and S2, and characterized by XRD, FTIR, TEM, SEM and TGA.

sec.title: XRD analysis
sec.p: XRD analysis is a powerful technique to prove the surfactants interclated into the interlamellar space of bentonite. Figure 7(a) to (c) illustrates the XRD patterns of bentonite, bentonite-S1 and bentonite-S2, respectively. One can see from Figure 7 that bentonite shows a characteristic diffraction peak at 2θ = 7.2°, which is assigned to the interlayer platelet spacing (001 diffraction peak, a spacing of 11.84 Å). However, a displacement of the peak to lower angles (2θ = 5.29° and 4.97°) is observed for the treated clay with the surfactants S1 and S2, which, as deduced by the Bragg’s law equation, corresponds to an interlayer distance of 16.67 and 17.75 Å, respectively. The result indicates the successful formation of the intercalated bentonite with surfactants S1 and S2 modification. 19

caption.p: X-Ray diffraction patterns of (a) unmodified bentonite, (b) bentonite-S1 and (c) bentonite-S2.

sec.title: FTIR analysis
sec.p: To further confirm the nature of modification and functional group attachment, FTIR analysis was conducted and peaks analyzed. Figure 8(a) to (c) shows the infrared spectra of bentonite, bentonite-S1 and bentonite-S2, respectively. At 3634, 3440, 1641, 1046, 918, 800 and 798 cm−1 bands, the peaks for both bentonite and modified bentonite (bentonite-S1 and bentonite-S2) samples are the same. But the modified bentonite samples show the characteristic absorption bands of symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibration of the CH2 and CH3 at around 2930, 2850 and 1475 cm−1. These functional groups attachment with carbon content implies that the surfactant (S1 and S2)-treated bentonite clay sample will be more organophilic and less hydrophilic and in turn found better application in polymer composite preparation to the unmodified bentonite. These results further indicate that the treated bentonite presents a hydrophobic nature and that the surfactants (S1 and S2) have been incorporated within the silicate layers. Similar results were obtained by López-Manchado et al. 19

caption.p: Fourier transform infrared spectra of (a) unmodified bentonite, (b) bentonite-S1 and (c) bentonite-S2.

sec.title: Thermogravimetric analysis
sec.p:
Thermoanalytical studies can lead to new insights into the structure of intercalated clays. 20
–23 Often, the way in which the weight steps occur provides information on the structure of the inserting molecules. Figure 9(a) to (c) show TGA curves of both the pure unmodified bentonite and modified bentonite with surfactants (S1 and S2). The weight loss is obvious in both samples between 30 and 150°C due to the evaporation of water of hydration in the inorganic cations and those absorbed in the aluminosilicate surfaces. Above 150°C, the weight loss in the pure unmodified bentonite reduces until it becomes stable at temperature above 600°C. 24 While, in the bentonite-S1 and bentonite-S2 (Figure 9(b) and (c)), the loss in weight increases. This can be attributed to the evaporation/decomposition of the loaded surfactants. This is justified by the results of FTIR. Figure 8 shows different functional groups attached to the surface of the bentonite. 25

caption.p: Thermogravimetric analysis of (a) unmodified bentonite, (b) bentonite-S1 and (c) bentonite-S2.

sec.title: Transmission electron microscopy
sec.p: Transmission electron micrographs for the bentonite and modified bentonite are presented in Figure 10(a) to (c). It is clear from this figure that the particle diameters are measured to be 1 and 23 µ, 10 nm for Na-bentonite, bentonite-S1 and bentonite-S2, respectively. According to a comparison with the TEM results reported in our earlier article, this has a higher structure. 26 The transmission electron micrographs confirm the XRD results.

caption.p: Transmission electron micrographs of (a) unmodified bentonite at 20 kx, (b) bentonite-S1 at 200 kx, and (c) bentonite-S2 at 300 kx.

sec.title: Scanning electron microscopy
sec.p: The SEM is used to show the morphology of the clay surface, both unmodified and modified. Figure 11(a) to (c) shows the morphology of the untreated and treated bentonite particles. It can be seen that the particles tend to agglomerate regardless the nature of the clay. Also, it can be seen that the size of the agglomeration of particles decrease in modified bentonites than unmodified bentonite.

caption.p: Scanning electron micrographs of (a) unmodified bentonite, (b) bentonite-S1 and (c) bentonite-S2.

sec.title: Curing characteristics
sec.p: The curing characteristics of the compounds are expressed in terms of minimum and maximum values of torque (M L and M H, respectively), their difference (M H − M L), the optimum cure time (Tc90), the scorch time (Ts2), their difference (Tc90 − Ts2) and the cure rate index (CRI), which are compiled in Table 3. Unmodified bentonite hardly varies the cure characteristics of the rubber, probably due to a poor compatibility between the unmodified clay and hydrophobic polymer. The torque value (ΔM = M H − M L) increases in the presence of organobentonite. This suggests that the organobentonite significantly increases the cross-link density of SBR, since the torque difference is related to the cross-link density. 27,28 However, the optimum cure time, Tc90, was sharply reduced in the presence of organobentonite. Thus, the organobentonite behaves as an effective accelerant agent for SBR vulcanization. This effect is attributed to the ammonium groups of the organic cations. In fact, amine groups facilitate the curing reaction of SBR and NR stocks. 29 –31 Due to the same reason, the CRI was higher in compounds containing organobentonite. The possible formation of a Zn complex in which sulfur and ammonium modifier participate may facilitate the formation of cross-links. The existence of a Zn–sulfur–amine complex has been suggested in the previous literature. 32 –34

caption.p: Rheometric characteristics of SBR compound at 152 ± 1°C.

fn.p: SBR: styrene-butadiene rubber; ML: minimum torque; MH: maximum torque; Tc90: optimum cure time; Ts2: scorch time; CRI: cure rate index; ΔM = M H − M L; ΔT = Tc90 − Ts2.

sec.title: Mechanical properties
sec.p: Table 4 shows the effect of organobentonite loading on the mechanical properties of SBR/organobentonite compounds. One can recognize that the tensile strength increases with the nanosilicate content. The same trend was recorded in case of the modulus at 100% elongation, which is a measure of stiffness of the rubber compounds. The elongation at break of the compounds remains unaffected with the incorporation of clay. 35

caption.p: Mechanical properties of pure SBR and its composites.

sec.p: Regarding hardness values, which can be seen in Table 3, the presence of clay in the SBR matrix increases this property.

sec.title: Cross-linking density
sec.p:
The swelling data were utilized to determine the molecular weight between two successive cross-links (M c) using Flory–Rehner relationship. 36,37

where ρ is the density of rubber, Vs is the molar volume of solvent (toluene), Vr is the volume fraction of the swollen rubber, and χ is the interaction parameter between the rubber and toluene.

The cross-linking density can be calculated from the equation 3
v =
1
1

M c
2
M c

The results are reported in Table 3. The cross-linking density of the pure SBR is reduced by the addition of bentonite, probably due to the incompatibility between both the phases. The cross-linking density increases with the presence of organobentonite, probably due to the interactions between the clay and the cure system as well as due to the compatibility between both the phases, which does allow the formation of additional cross-links. These results agree with the Monsanto measurements, indicating the good compatibility between the organobentonite and SBR.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this study, two cationic surfactants (S1 and S2) have been synthesized. Organobentonites are prepared by ion exchange process using these surfactants (S1 and S2) as modifying agents. The XRD, FTIR, TGA, SEM and TEM analyses show that both the surfactants were intercalated into bentonite. The incorporation of organically modified and unmodified bentonites in SBR matrix by two roll mill mixing shows higher torque and larger torque difference than the SBR with unmodified bentonite. The optimum cure time (T 90), scorch time (T 2) and their difference (T 90 − T 2) of SBR/organonentonite are much more reduced than those of SBR/bentonite, which concludes that organobentonites behave as an effective accelerant agent for SBR vulcanization. Also, organobentonites increase the tensile strength, modulus at 100% elongation and hardness values, but the elongation at break is not affected.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
